author: jeff
post: No, his doubt in such a situation is based on the known facts — patterns, if you will — of human behavior. Plausibility is a comparative concept and is dependent on knowledge. Whether we realize it consciously or not, human beings have a vast data warehouse against which we compare our every observation. So, saying “I doubt your account” is really saying “Your explanation does not comport with the facts as I understand them” or perhaps “Your account is inconsistent with my previous observations of human behavior.”.
title: Mystery as Proof
